snippet: A study comparing preschoolers’ puzzle-solving strategies with those of chimps and monkeys highlights humans’ unique “cumulative culture” of shared knowledge.
abstract: Study in journal Science finds that monkeys and chimpanzees, unlike human children, will not aid each other in completing tasks such as completing a puzzle; researchers conclude that primates lack the capacity for 'cumulative culture,' which has allowed human beings to improve upon the accomplishments and knowledge of their peers and predecessors.
lead_paragraph: A study comparing preschoolers’ puzzle-solving strategies with those of chimps and monkeys highlights humans’ unique “cumulative culture” of shared knowledge.

headline.print_headline: With Teamwork, Humans Best Other Primates
headline.main: With Teamwork, Humans Best Other Primates
